desc00: The game above is completely parameterized by the JSON file you see
desc01: before you. This is by design -- the intent for this mahjong client
desc02: is to be a universal mahjong engine. The engine has no notion
desc03: of 'tanyao' or 'tenpai' -- those are mere words in a JSON file that
desc04: the engine blindly interprets. Yaku is customizable, calls are
desc05: customizable, even the auto buttons on the bottom are customizable.
desc06: The major design goal is to be able to play any variant of mahjong out
desc07: there -- Hong Kong, American, Saki-power-infused mahjong. We're not
desc08: quite there yet, but the fact that we've implemented Riichi, one of
desc09: the most complex variants, means many other variants will soon meet
desc10: the same fate. (I tried to hardcode as little as possible when writing
desc11: the Riichi ruleset, but there are still some things that are
desc12: non-configurable, namely fu calculation and score adjudication.)
desc13: I plan to write comprehensive documentation for this thing, but I'm
desc14: still in the process of simplifying the specification, so it might
desc15: take a while before documentation is out.
desc16: Currently there is no way to user-submit a custom ruleset other than
desc17: sending it to me on Discord. Feel free to do that, by the way, if for
desc18: some reason you get into the mood of writing a custom ruleset!
